VOL. XX, NO. 12.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 17, 1916.

Dr. Ira Remsen, president emeritus of Johns Hopkins University,
Spoke at the annual banquet of the
American Institute of Chemical Engineers last Thursday evening on
the necessity of keeping the spirit
of research alive in America.
Dr. Remsen said that he was in
Germany at the time of the birth
of the new chemical era, and had
Witnessed the inauguration of the
newer chemical industries which are
now playing such an important part
in the war.
"Liebig," Dr. Remsen said, "was
the father of the movement. It was
he who taught Germany that the
knowledge of science and the spirit
of investigation were essential to the
welfare of industry."
"To promote its industrial industries," Dr. Remsen proceeded,"Germany had taken men out of its
universities to head its great concerns, and the success of those concerns had been the proof of the
Wisdom of Germany's policy."
Dr. Remsen went on to say that
this country needs the things which
Germany has won as the result of
this policy. The recent address of
President Perkins, of the English
Chemical Society, showed that England is suffering for them, and
although the United States is in a
better condition than England in regard to chemical education and
training, this country still has much
to learn.
"The word 'research,'" Dr. Remsen continued, "has been much
abused in America, especially in
schools and colleges. And in the
schools and colleges it is a sham.
No one can do true research work
until he puts his whole body and
soul into it. It requires and demands everything there is in a man.
It is impossible in colleges for students to do 'original research work,'
because their energies are necessarily dissipated in the study of
several subjects. There is a great
deal of humbug in our so-called research work. But we are improving tremendously. We must get
the true spirit into the right men
and then place these men in the
lead. We have a long road to travel
before we attain the real goal, but
We are on the right road and we
are traveling."
The convention inspected several
Plants, both in this city and in Annapolis, during the three days it
was in session. The banquet, of
Whch Dr. Charles McKenna was
toastmaster, was held at the Emerson Hotel.

DR. REID BACK FROM PANAMA

SECOND COTILLON FEBRUARY 4

Will Report Investigation of Canal Slides
to President Wilson Much of Geological Interest Met in Zone.

Elaborate Preparations Under Way for
Next Dance of Season—Freshmen,
Particularly, Asked to Attend.

Dr. Harry Fielding Reid, professor of dynamic geology and
geography in this university, has returned from his trip to the Panama
Canal, and is preparing to report
to President Wilson the results of
the investigation he made with other
scientists. The committee, with Dr.
C. R. Van Hise, president of the
University of Wisconsin, as chairman, spent a month in Panama
looking into the phenomena attending the slides which have occasioned
so much trouble of late.
Dr. Reid, who returned to Baltimore on Friday, said yesterday at
his home, 6o8 Cathedral Street, that
neither he nor any member of the
party that went to the Canal Zone
could discuss the slides at the waterway until after the report was in
the President's hands.
Leaving this city December 8
last, Professor Reid was joined at
New Orelans by eight other scientists—Dr. Van Hise, H. L. Abbott
and J. C. Branner of Leland Stanford University; Whitman Cross,
United States Geological Survey;
John F. Hayford, Northwestern
University; R. C. Carpenter, Cornell University; A. P. Davis, Reclamation Service, and John R.
Freeman, Providence, R. I. It was
Professor Reid's first trip to the
Canal Zone and he said he was
much interested in the canal work
and in the geological formations
that were encountered.

The Cotillon Board is making
elaborate preparations for the second of the series of formal dances,
which will be held on Friday night,
February 4, in McCoy Hall.
The music, which will be furnished by Louis Fischer"s orchestra, has been given special attention. The program will include
twenty dances, in addition to the
usual encores. The committee,
which was appointed to wait upon
Dean Brush, announces that he has
given special permission to continue
until 12.30 o'clock.
As it has been the custom in the
past, all alumni who are not students in the University will be admitted at the usual price of $1.50;
while $2.50 will be charged all students.
In view of the limited representation of the Freshman class at the
last cotillon, the committee wishes
to extend particularly an invitation
to each member of this class. All
those who are interested should see
R. G. Merrick, '17, immediately, so
that definite preparation may be
made now.

Prof. Crane to Speak on Boccaccio.

Prof. J. F. Crane will speak to the
Philological Association of Johns
Hopkins University on Friday, January 21, in the Donovan room, on
Boccaccio's Decameron. All are
cordially invited.

pool. The,,$io,000 subscribed by

Tenors Respond to Call Made by Glee
Club—Special Rate Offered to Undergraduates for McCoy Hall Concert.

The Glee Club made rapid progress during the past week. Following the call for tenors sent out a
week ago, a large number of competent men reported for practice,
and with this gap filled, work on the
music went ahead at a rate far exceeding anything yet attained this
year. With the addition of one or
two numbers to the repertoire thus
far gained, the club will be in excellent shape. .
The Mandolin Club, while not as
far advanced in its work as the
singers, still looks promising, and
with more frequent rehearsal from
now on will show results. The fact
that many of the instrumentalists
are at Homewood this year has
made it difficult to systematize the
organization, but this trouble once
out of the way a short time will suffice for the perfection of the program. Affairs ill general are picking up at a rapid rate.
The musicians are bending all of
their efforts toward making the big
concert in McCoy Hall a success.
A tentative program recently compiled by the director shows that it
will be the snappiest concert of its
kind given at Hopkins in many
years. The repertoire of the clubs
includes a variety of numbers which
would be hard to duplicate; the aim
has been to satisfy, as far as possible, all kinds of musical taste, and
the public is assured by the management that there will be something
on the bill to suit everybody.
The committee in charge of the
McCoy Hall Concert announces that
undergraduate students will be
given the privilege of buying a
"blue ticket" which may be exchanged for two reserved seats, and
which will sell for $1.50. This reduction is being made as an effort
to increase the attendance of students as much as possible, and, if
enough undergraduates take advantage of it to justify its continuance, it will be offered as a feature
of succeeding concerts. Each undergraduate will be allowed to buy
one ticket.
Other concert engagements have
been arranged and the schedule is
fast assuming its final shape. One
or two trips, details of which will be
announced shortly, will be taken.
The musicians have a promising
field in which to do their work, and
if they continue at their present rate
of progress their chances for success are unlimited.
The custom of having the freshmen wear distinctive hats is an innovation this year at Missouri.—Ex.

The Adams debate committee has
received word from the committee
of the Philodemic Society of
Georgetown that all the contentions
which they had made in regard to
the conducting of the debate have
been conceded.
The Adams Society, which is
debating the negative of the question, "Resolved: That the term
of the president should be made
six years and that he should be
ineligible to re-election," objected
to certain conditions which the
last letter received from Georgetown had favored. These included
the bestowal of the last speech upon
the affirmative rebuttal speaker instead of upon the negative, and the
holding- of the debate upon a Sunday night.
Previous to the granting of these
conditions by Georgetown, the
Adams had agreed to a postponement of the debate, and to an arrangement in which the three speakers on each side are to handle their
individual rebuttals, instead of there
being two main speakers and one rebuttal.
It now -seems probable that the
debate will take place in the middle
of February. The Georgetown debaters seem to favor this date, and
it is agreeable to the Hopkins men,
as it comes long enough after the
Inter-class Debate and the Adams
Medal Contest on the night of January 28 to permit of sufficient time
being given to a careful and thorough preparation before the trip to
Washington is undertaken.
The choice of a subject is regarded as particularly fortunate. It will
be debated at a time when the active
discussion of the single term principle will be before the country, and
should provide an interesting evening for both speakers and audience.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 17, 1916.

It is with regret that we announce
the resignation of Mr. Thomas J.
Tingley,'16, from the editorial staff
of THE NEWS-LZTTER. Mr. Tingley was elected to a position On the
board in his junior year, and was
always faithful and efficient in the
performance of his duties.. He has
found it necessary to give up his
place on Tilt Ntws-LETTER on account of pressure of work on the
debating teams and on the 1916
Hullabaloo, of which he is editorin-chief.
THE NEWS-LETTER wishes Mr.
Tingley the best of good fortune
in his work on the Hullabaloo.
Think of the Future!

The time is at hand when the
directors of the activities of late
winter and early spring are taking
up their work in earnest, striving
with their charges for a worthy representation on athletic field, concert
stage and debating platform. Their
work is at present in the formative
period of its development; faults are
being corrected, good points rounded out, and a•systematic procedure
along lines most conducive to success is being sought. And for this
work, men are needed.
We must bear in mind that if the

teams and clubs which promise to
represent Johns Hopkins with flying colors this year are to continue
their work in years to come, material must be put into shape to take
up the places of those men who
must be lost by graduation. Our
lacrosse squad gives promise of
turning out a championship team
this year, but Coach Wolfe has announced that unless a larger delegation from the freshman class
comes out, the chances for a winning team next year and the years
following are not good at all. The
baseball team, musical clubs, and debating teams all have men enough
on their lists of candidates to carry
them through this season with the
expected success, but as matters
stand now none can boast that its
needs will be definitely provided for
during the next few years. The
standing of future student organizations depends on the spirit with
which the under-classmen of today
undertake to train themselves to fill
positions which will be left open for
juniors and seniors of tomorrow.
Men thoroughly qualified to take
up this work are not made in a day,
nor are they endowed by Providence with the ability to take up
their-duties without sincere preparatory work. Their powers must be
developed by dint of persevering
application to the task of learning their part in the line of work
which they have chosen to follow,
and they can combine to make up an
effective unit only when they have
followed such a course. The
"green" freshman with only a
moderate amount of natural ability
who chooses his activity, enlists in
its work, and, without scattering his
energy, puts himself to the task of
mastering its details, sticking to it
until results show, is more than apt
to be the man who will be ready
when occasion demands an efficient
player to fill a position on his team.
Now, then, is the time for freshmen to begin their training. Many
a college man reaches his senior
year with the regret that he did not
enter into some activity as an under-classman, realizing to his sorrow that it is too late to do anything worth while. Under-classmen, you can avoid such a predicament by deciding now to amount to
something in the .activity best suited to your personal ability. Choose
your work, give it your energy, and
stick to it!

INTER-CLASS BASKET-BALL
TEAMS ELECTS OFFICERS

At a meeting held in the Trophy
Room on January ii, inter-class
basket-ball teams were organized.
Each class was represented by two
delegates and from this body the
following temporary officers were
chosen: Nathaniel M. Beck, '16,
chairman; Emil Rosenthal, '16, secretary.
Any undergraduate is eligible to
a place on his class team if the
other coaches do not object. No
freshman who has not attended the
gymnasium regularly will be eligible. It was decided that each
team should play twelve games.
Mr. Kistler was appointed a committee of one to draw up a schedule
and submit it to the approval of the
Board. The committee announces
that prizes will be awarded to the
seven men who make the best showing and who participate in not less
than three-fourths of the games.
The players must bind themselves
to complete the schedule.
The following delegates were sent
from their respective classes: Senior, N. M. Beck and Emil Rosenthal; junior, W. A. McKewen and
C. P. Boyce; sophomore, W. S.
Love, Jr. and S. W.Egerton; freshman, M. Marty and K. 0. Bitter.
The members of each class will elect
a captain and a manager, who, in
conjunction with Mr. Kistler, will
have charge of picking the teams
from the material which presents
itself.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 17, 1916.

HOPKINS MAN TO FORD HOSPITAL

RIFLE CLUB SCHEDULE OUT

Dr. Roy D. McClure, of Hospital Staff,
Goes to Detroit—Is Second Hopkins
Doctor to Take Up Work There.

Twelve Matches to Be Shot with Other
College Teams in League -Prospects
for Good Team Bright.

Dr. Roy D. McClure, of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital, has accepted the position of surgeon-inchief at the Henry Ford Hospital
in Detroit.
Dr. McClure is thirty-four years
old, and is a native of Dayton,
Ohio. He received the degree of
bachelor of arts from the Ohio
State University, and was graduated from the Johns Hopkins Medical School in 1908. Immediately
after his graduation, he was given
a position with the Rockefeller
Institute of Research, where he
worked for a year with the famous
surgeon, Dr. Alexis Carrel. During this time, he spent a few months
abroad, at the University of Prague.
Dr. McClure was next appointed
to the surgical staff of the New
York Hospital, where he again
proved his remarkable ability. He
served on this staff for three years,
and then returned to the Johns
Hopkins Hospital as assistant resident surgeon. Two years ago, he
was appointed resident surgeon.
Dr. McClure is the second Hopkins man to be connected with the
Ford Hospital. Dr. Frank J. Sladen, former resident physician at
Hopkins, it now its resident physician. In addition, Dr. James
Smith, former medical-physician at
Hopkins, is now chief medicalphysician at the Western Hospital
in Detroit. All of these appointments, which prove the reputation
enjoyed by the Hopkins Hospital,
have been made since January,
1915.
The Ford Hospital has been
founded only recently, and is one
of the finest institutions of its kind
in the world. It has now about
three hundred beds, and is planned
eventually to have room for two
thousand patients.

The MN\ ly-organized Johns Hopkins Rifle Club has been fortunate
in getting a good start. Much interest has been taken in the work,
and prospects for a good season are
very favorable. The Hopkins team
is a member of the American Rifle
Club Association, and, as such, will
match all the other teams affiliated.
Each team shoots on its own range,
and the targets are sent to headquarters, where results are compared.
The team consists of ten men, but
only the five best scores are counted.
A record of each man has been
kept for the whole year, and those
who have made the best showing
will be chosen. Hopkins has already held a match with Connecticut Agricultural College, but as yet
the results have not been announced.
The next match is with Penn State
College.
The remainder of the schedule is
as follows:
January 29—Iowa State College.
February 5—Ohio State University.
February 19—Williams College.
February 26—Columbia University.
March 4—College of St. Thomas.
March 'i—Lehigh University.
March 18—Oregon Agricultural
College.
March 25—Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
April 1—Harvard.
April 8 Renseler Polytechnic
Institute.

The Glee Club of the University
of Ohio completed during the holidays the longest trip it has ever
undertaken. The tour lasted ten
days and included the important
cities in Western Pennsylvania and
in Ohio.—Ex.
The chemistry laboratory of New
York University was partially destroyed by fire on December 30,
said to have been caused by spontaneous combustion. Besides damage to the building and the loss of
a supply of chemicals, many of the
students who are majoring in chemistry had theses destroyed, on which
they had been working for several
years.
The University of Pennsylvania
has secured the services of Robert
C. Folwell as head coach of the
next year's football team. Folwell
is the former Washington and Jefferson coach.

MONOGRAPH ON BOYCOTT
Large Dining Room on Second Floor

Among other items of note in recent publications of the Johns Hopkins Press is a monograph on "The
Boycott inAmerican Trade Unions,"
written by Leo Wolman, Ph. D.,
Fellow in Political Economy. While
a member of the economic seminary
at this University, Dr. Wolman carried out an investigation of boycotts, gathering his data from the
University library and through personal interviews with trade union
officials and employers.
After discussing the nature of the
boycott, and furnishing numerous
concise definitions, he gives its history, citing incidents as far back as
the time when the "Jews shunned
the Samaritans," and then dwells
upon the history of the boycott in
America. In addition to this there
are chapters devoted to the discussion of boycott on materials and
commodities, on the mechanism of
the boycott, and on the law and the
boycott. Dr. Wolman gives excellent examples and has supplemented
his work with notes.

Chicago, Ill., Dr. Knight Dunlap,
an associate professor of psychology at Johns Hopkins, exhibited a
chronoscope of his own invention.
The instrument is used in an association reaction experiment, which
is performed in the following manner: The experimenter says a word,
and, as the air waves caused by his
voice make a plate vibrate, an electrical connection is broken and a
clock starts. When the subject replies, another plate is set vibrating,
and, making a connection, stops the
clock. The object of the experiment is to find the length of time
it takes for different kinds of associations of ideas to form. For
instance, it can be found whether
it takes longer for an adjective or
a verb to suggest itself when a
noun is spoken. The chronoscope
measures time to one-thousandth of
a second.
This apparatus, which is the first
of its kind, met with great approval
at the Chicago convention, and orders for duplicates have been given
by many of the leading universities
of the country. The chronoscopes
will be made in the Johns Hopkins
psychological laboratory.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 17, 1916.

Dr. Ira Remsen, president emeritus of Johns Hopkins University,
Spoke at the annual banquet of the
American Institute of Chemical Engineers last Thursday evening on
the necessity of keeping the spirit
of research alive in America.
Dr. Remsen said that he was in
Germany at the time of the birth
of the new chemical era, and had
Witnessed the inauguration of the
newer chemical industries which are
now playing such an important part
in the war.
"Liebig," Dr. Remsen said, "was
the father of the movement. It was
he who taught Germany that the
knowledge of science and the spirit
of investigation were essential to the
welfare of industry."
"To promote its industrial industries," Dr. Remsen proceeded,"Germany had taken men out of its
universities to head its great concerns, and the success of those concerns had been the proof of the
Wisdom of Germany's policy."
Dr. Remsen went on to say that
this country needs the things which
Germany has won as the result of
this policy. The recent address of
President Perkins, of the English
Chemical Society, showed that England is suffering for them, and
although the United States is in a
better condition than England in regard to chemical education and
training, this country still has much
to learn.
"The word 'research,'" Dr. Remsen continued, "has been much
abused in America, especially in
schools and colleges. And in the
schools and colleges it is a sham.
No one can do true research work
until he puts his whole body and
soul into it. It requires and demands everything there is in a man.
It is impossible in colleges for students to do 'original research work,'
because their energies are necessarily dissipated in the study of
several subjects. There is a great
deal of humbug in our so-called research work. But we are improving tremendously. We must get
the true spirit into the right men
and then place these men in the
lead. We have a long road to travel
before we attain the real goal, but
We are on the right road and we
are traveling."
The convention inspected several
Plants, both in this city and in Annapolis, during the three days it
was in session. The banquet, of
Whch Dr. Charles McKenna was
toastmaster, was held at the Emerson Hotel.

DR. REID BACK FROM PANAMA

SECOND COTILLON FEBRUARY 4

Will Report Investigation of Canal Slides
to President Wilson Much of Geological Interest Met in Zone.

Elaborate Preparations Under Way for
Next Dance of Season—Freshmen,
Particularly, Asked to Attend.

Dr. Harry Fielding Reid, professor of dynamic geology and
geography in this university, has returned from his trip to the Panama
Canal, and is preparing to report
to President Wilson the results of
the investigation he made with other
scientists. The committee, with Dr.
C. R. Van Hise, president of the
University of Wisconsin, as chairman, spent a month in Panama
looking into the phenomena attending the slides which have occasioned
so much trouble of late.
Dr. Reid, who returned to Baltimore on Friday, said yesterday at
his home, 6o8 Cathedral Street, that
neither he nor any member of the
party that went to the Canal Zone
could discuss the slides at the waterway until after the report was in
the President's hands.
Leaving this city December 8
last, Professor Reid was joined at
New Orelans by eight other scientists—Dr. Van Hise, H. L. Abbott
and J. C. Branner of Leland Stanford University; Whitman Cross,
United States Geological Survey;
John F. Hayford, Northwestern
University; R. C. Carpenter, Cornell University; A. P. Davis, Reclamation Service, and John R.
Freeman, Providence, R. I. It was
Professor Reid's first trip to the
Canal Zone and he said he was
much interested in the canal work
and in the geological formations
that were encountered.

The Cotillon Board is making
elaborate preparations for the second of the series of formal dances,
which will be held on Friday night,
February 4, in McCoy Hall.
The music, which will be furnished by Louis Fischer"s orchestra, has been given special attention. The program will include
twenty dances, in addition to the
usual encores. The committee,
which was appointed to wait upon
Dean Brush, announces that he has
given special permission to continue
until 12.30 o'clock.
As it has been the custom in the
past, all alumni who are not students in the University will be admitted at the usual price of $1.50;
while $2.50 will be charged all students.
In view of the limited representation of the Freshman class at the
last cotillon, the committee wishes
to extend particularly an invitation
to each member of this class. All
those who are interested should see
R. G. Merrick, '17, immediately, so
that definite preparation may be
made now.

Prof. Crane to Speak on Boccaccio.

Prof. J. F. Crane will speak to the
Philological Association of Johns
Hopkins University on Friday, January 21, in the Donovan room, on
Boccaccio's Decameron. All are
cordially invited.

pool. The,,$io,000 subscribed by

Tenors Respond to Call Made by Glee
Club—Special Rate Offered to Undergraduates for McCoy Hall Concert.

The Glee Club made rapid progress during the past week. Following the call for tenors sent out a
week ago, a large number of competent men reported for practice,
and with this gap filled, work on the
music went ahead at a rate far exceeding anything yet attained this
year. With the addition of one or
two numbers to the repertoire thus
far gained, the club will be in excellent shape. .
The Mandolin Club, while not as
far advanced in its work as the
singers, still looks promising, and
with more frequent rehearsal from
now on will show results. The fact
that many of the instrumentalists
are at Homewood this year has
made it difficult to systematize the
organization, but this trouble once
out of the way a short time will suffice for the perfection of the program. Affairs ill general are picking up at a rapid rate.
The musicians are bending all of
their efforts toward making the big
concert in McCoy Hall a success.
A tentative program recently compiled by the director shows that it
will be the snappiest concert of its
kind given at Hopkins in many
years. The repertoire of the clubs
includes a variety of numbers which
would be hard to duplicate; the aim
has been to satisfy, as far as possible, all kinds of musical taste, and
the public is assured by the management that there will be something
on the bill to suit everybody.
The committee in charge of the
McCoy Hall Concert announces that
undergraduate students will be
given the privilege of buying a
"blue ticket" which may be exchanged for two reserved seats, and
which will sell for $1.50. This reduction is being made as an effort
to increase the attendance of students as much as possible, and, if
enough undergraduates take advantage of it to justify its continuance, it will be offered as a feature
of succeeding concerts. Each undergraduate will be allowed to buy
one ticket.
Other concert engagements have
been arranged and the schedule is
fast assuming its final shape. One
or two trips, details of which will be
announced shortly, will be taken.
The musicians have a promising
field in which to do their work, and
if they continue at their present rate
of progress their chances for success are unlimited.
The custom of having the freshmen wear distinctive hats is an innovation this year at Missouri.—Ex.

The Adams debate committee has
received word from the committee
of the Philodemic Society of
Georgetown that all the contentions
which they had made in regard to
the conducting of the debate have
been conceded.
The Adams Society, which is
debating the negative of the question, "Resolved: That the term
of the president should be made
six years and that he should be
ineligible to re-election," objected
to certain conditions which the
last letter received from Georgetown had favored. These included
the bestowal of the last speech upon
the affirmative rebuttal speaker instead of upon the negative, and the
holding- of the debate upon a Sunday night.
Previous to the granting of these
conditions by Georgetown, the
Adams had agreed to a postponement of the debate, and to an arrangement in which the three speakers on each side are to handle their
individual rebuttals, instead of there
being two main speakers and one rebuttal.
It now -seems probable that the
debate will take place in the middle
of February. The Georgetown debaters seem to favor this date, and
it is agreeable to the Hopkins men,
as it comes long enough after the
Inter-class Debate and the Adams
Medal Contest on the night of January 28 to permit of sufficient time
being given to a careful and thorough preparation before the trip to
Washington is undertaken.
The choice of a subject is regarded as particularly fortunate. It will
be debated at a time when the active
discussion of the single term principle will be before the country, and
should provide an interesting evening for both speakers and audience.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 17, 1916.

It is with regret that we announce
the resignation of Mr. Thomas J.
Tingley,'16, from the editorial staff
of THE NEWS-LZTTER. Mr. Tingley was elected to a position On the
board in his junior year, and was
always faithful and efficient in the
performance of his duties.. He has
found it necessary to give up his
place on Tilt Ntws-LETTER on account of pressure of work on the
debating teams and on the 1916
Hullabaloo, of which he is editorin-chief.
THE NEWS-LETTER wishes Mr.
Tingley the best of good fortune
in his work on the Hullabaloo.
Think of the Future!

The time is at hand when the
directors of the activities of late
winter and early spring are taking
up their work in earnest, striving
with their charges for a worthy representation on athletic field, concert
stage and debating platform. Their
work is at present in the formative
period of its development; faults are
being corrected, good points rounded out, and a•systematic procedure
along lines most conducive to success is being sought. And for this
work, men are needed.
We must bear in mind that if the

teams and clubs which promise to
represent Johns Hopkins with flying colors this year are to continue
their work in years to come, material must be put into shape to take
up the places of those men who
must be lost by graduation. Our
lacrosse squad gives promise of
turning out a championship team
this year, but Coach Wolfe has announced that unless a larger delegation from the freshman class
comes out, the chances for a winning team next year and the years
following are not good at all. The
baseball team, musical clubs, and debating teams all have men enough
on their lists of candidates to carry
them through this season with the
expected success, but as matters
stand now none can boast that its
needs will be definitely provided for
during the next few years. The
standing of future student organizations depends on the spirit with
which the under-classmen of today
undertake to train themselves to fill
positions which will be left open for
juniors and seniors of tomorrow.
Men thoroughly qualified to take
up this work are not made in a day,
nor are they endowed by Providence with the ability to take up
their-duties without sincere preparatory work. Their powers must be
developed by dint of persevering
application to the task of learning their part in the line of work
which they have chosen to follow,
and they can combine to make up an
effective unit only when they have
followed such a course. The
"green" freshman with only a
moderate amount of natural ability
who chooses his activity, enlists in
its work, and, without scattering his
energy, puts himself to the task of
mastering its details, sticking to it
until results show, is more than apt
to be the man who will be ready
when occasion demands an efficient
player to fill a position on his team.
Now, then, is the time for freshmen to begin their training. Many
a college man reaches his senior
year with the regret that he did not
enter into some activity as an under-classman, realizing to his sorrow that it is too late to do anything worth while. Under-classmen, you can avoid such a predicament by deciding now to amount to
something in the .activity best suited to your personal ability. Choose
your work, give it your energy, and
stick to it!

INTER-CLASS BASKET-BALL
TEAMS ELECTS OFFICERS

At a meeting held in the Trophy
Room on January ii, inter-class
basket-ball teams were organized.
Each class was represented by two
delegates and from this body the
following temporary officers were
chosen: Nathaniel M. Beck, '16,
chairman; Emil Rosenthal, '16, secretary.
Any undergraduate is eligible to
a place on his class team if the
other coaches do not object. No
freshman who has not attended the
gymnasium regularly will be eligible. It was decided that each
team should play twelve games.
Mr. Kistler was appointed a committee of one to draw up a schedule
and submit it to the approval of the
Board. The committee announces
that prizes will be awarded to the
seven men who make the best showing and who participate in not less
than three-fourths of the games.
The players must bind themselves
to complete the schedule.
The following delegates were sent
from their respective classes: Senior, N. M. Beck and Emil Rosenthal; junior, W. A. McKewen and
C. P. Boyce; sophomore, W. S.
Love, Jr. and S. W.Egerton; freshman, M. Marty and K. 0. Bitter.
The members of each class will elect
a captain and a manager, who, in
conjunction with Mr. Kistler, will
have charge of picking the teams
from the material which presents
itself.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 17, 1916.

HOPKINS MAN TO FORD HOSPITAL

RIFLE CLUB SCHEDULE OUT

Dr. Roy D. McClure, of Hospital Staff,
Goes to Detroit—Is Second Hopkins
Doctor to Take Up Work There.

Twelve Matches to Be Shot with Other
College Teams in League -Prospects
for Good Team Bright.

Dr. Roy D. McClure, of the
Johns Hopkins Hospital, has accepted the position of surgeon-inchief at the Henry Ford Hospital
in Detroit.
Dr. McClure is thirty-four years
old, and is a native of Dayton,
Ohio. He received the degree of
bachelor of arts from the Ohio
State University, and was graduated from the Johns Hopkins Medical School in 1908. Immediately
after his graduation, he was given
a position with the Rockefeller
Institute of Research, where he
worked for a year with the famous
surgeon, Dr. Alexis Carrel. During this time, he spent a few months
abroad, at the University of Prague.
Dr. McClure was next appointed
to the surgical staff of the New
York Hospital, where he again
proved his remarkable ability. He
served on this staff for three years,
and then returned to the Johns
Hopkins Hospital as assistant resident surgeon. Two years ago, he
was appointed resident surgeon.
Dr. McClure is the second Hopkins man to be connected with the
Ford Hospital. Dr. Frank J. Sladen, former resident physician at
Hopkins, it now its resident physician. In addition, Dr. James
Smith, former medical-physician at
Hopkins, is now chief medicalphysician at the Western Hospital
in Detroit. All of these appointments, which prove the reputation
enjoyed by the Hopkins Hospital,
have been made since January,
1915.
The Ford Hospital has been
founded only recently, and is one
of the finest institutions of its kind
in the world. It has now about
three hundred beds, and is planned
eventually to have room for two
thousand patients.

The MN\ ly-organized Johns Hopkins Rifle Club has been fortunate
in getting a good start. Much interest has been taken in the work,
and prospects for a good season are
very favorable. The Hopkins team
is a member of the American Rifle
Club Association, and, as such, will
match all the other teams affiliated.
Each team shoots on its own range,
and the targets are sent to headquarters, where results are compared.
The team consists of ten men, but
only the five best scores are counted.
A record of each man has been
kept for the whole year, and those
who have made the best showing
will be chosen. Hopkins has already held a match with Connecticut Agricultural College, but as yet
the results have not been announced.
The next match is with Penn State
College.
The remainder of the schedule is
as follows:

February 5—Ohio State University.
February 19—Williams College.
February 26—Columbia University.
March 4—College of St. Thomas.

The Glee Club of the University
of Ohio completed during the holidays the longest trip it has ever
undertaken. The tour lasted ten
days and included the important
cities in Western Pennsylvania and
in Ohio.—Ex.

York University was partially destroyed by fire on December 30,
said to have been caused by spontaneous combustion. Besides damage to the building and the loss of
a supply of chemicals, many of the
students who are majoring in chemistry had theses destroyed, on which
they had been working for several
years.
The University of Pennsylvania
has secured the services of Robert
C. Folwell as head coach of the
next year's football team. Folwell
is the former Washington and Jefferson coach.

MONOGRAPH ON BOYCOTT
Large Dining Room on Second Floor

Among other items of note in recent publications of the Johns Hopkins Press is a monograph on "The
Boycott inAmerican Trade Unions,"
written by Leo Wolman, Ph. D.,
Fellow in Political Economy. While
a member of the economic seminary
at this University, Dr. Wolman carried out an investigation of boycotts, gathering his data from the
University library and through personal interviews with trade union
officials and employers.
After discussing the nature of the
boycott, and furnishing numerous
concise definitions, he gives its history, citing incidents as far back as
the time when the "Jews shunned
the Samaritans," and then dwells
upon the history of the boycott in
America. In addition to this there
are chapters devoted to the discussion of boycott on materials and
commodities, on the mechanism of
the boycott, and on the law and the
boycott. Dr. Wolman gives excellent examples and has supplemented
his work with notes.

Chicago, Ill., Dr. Knight Dunlap,
an associate professor of psychology at Johns Hopkins, exhibited a
chronoscope of his own invention.
The instrument is used in an association reaction experiment, which
is performed in the following manner: The experimenter says a word,
and, as the air waves caused by his
voice make a plate vibrate, an electrical connection is broken and a
clock starts. When the subject replies, another plate is set vibrating,
and, making a connection, stops the
clock. The object of the experiment is to find the length of time
it takes for different kinds of associations of ideas to form. For
instance, it can be found whether
it takes longer for an adjective or
a verb to suggest itself when a
noun is spoken. The chronoscope
measures time to one-thousandth of
a second.
This apparatus, which is the first
of its kind, met with great approval
at the Chicago convention, and orders for duplicates have been given
by many of the leading universities
of the country. The chronoscopes
will be made in the Johns Hopkins
psychological laboratory.

Gilmour Dobie, the famous football coach, who recently resigned
his position at the University of
Washington is much in demand.
Wisconsin and Minnesota are both
hot on his trail and there are other
colleges of less importance which
are making him offers. It will be
remembered that the Washington
team, under Dobie, went through
m years without losing a game.
This remarkable feat has put Dobie
in the eyes of the intercollegiate
public, and his resignation has been
followed by an avalanche of offers
to coach college teams all over the
Middle West.—Ex.
